questions.answer_description:
A: The APPEND keyword tells SQL*Loader to preserve any preexisting data in the table. Other options allow you to delete preexisting data, or to fail with an error if the table is not empty to begin with.
B (not D):
Note:
* SQL*Loader-00210: first data file is empty, cannot process the FIELD NAMES record
Cause: The data file listed in the next message was empty. Therefore, the FIELD NAMES FIRST FILE directive could not be processed.
Action: Check the listed data file and fix it. Then retry the operation
E:
* A comma-separated values (CSV) (also sometimes called character-separated values, because the separator character does not have to be a comma) file stores tabular data (numbers and text) in plain-text form. Plain text means that the file is a sequence of characters, with no data that has to be interpreted instead, as binary numbers. A CSV file consists of any number of records, separated by line breaks of some kind; each record consists of fields, separated by some other character or string, most commonly a literal comma or tab. Usually, all records have an identical sequence of fields.
* Fields with embedded commas must be quoted.
Example:
1997,Ford,E350,"Super, luxurious truck"
Note:
* SQL*Loader is a bulk loader utility used for moving data from external files into the Oracle database.

choices.C: The SQL* Loader operation fails because no record terminators are specified.
choices.E: The SQL* Loader operation assumes that the file must be a stream record format file with the normal carriage return string as the record terminator.
choices.A: An EMP table is created if a table does not exist. Otherwise, if the EMP table is appended with the loaded data.
choices.B: The SQL* Loader data file myfile1.dat has the column names for the EMP table.
choices.D: Field names should be the first line in the both the SQL* Loader data files.

choices.C: An extent cannot span data files.
choices.D: The size of an Oracle data block in a data file should be the same as the size of an OS block.
choices.A: A segment cannot span data files.
choices.B: A data file can belong to only one tablespace.

D is faulse because a datablock can store on or more OS blocks.... B,C are correct

questions.answer_description:
A single extent can never span data files.
https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/CNCPT/logical.htm#CNCPT1095
questions.question_text: Which two statements correctly describe the relationship between data files and logical database structures? (Choose two.)

questions.answer_description:
REVOKE ..FROM -
If the current container is the root:
/ Specify CONTAINER = CURRENT to revoke a locally granted system privilege, object privilege, or role from a common user or common role. The privilege or role is revoked from the user or role only in the root. This clause does not revoke privileges granted with CONTAINER = ALL.
/ Specify CONTAINER = ALL to revoke a commonly granted system privilege, object privilege on a common object, or role from a common user or common role.
The privilege or role is revoked from the user or role across the entire CDB. This clause can revoke only a privilege or role granted with CONTAINER = ALL from the specified common user or common role. This clause does not revoke privileges granted locally with CONTAINER = CURRENT. However, any locally granted privileges that depend on the commonly granted privilege being revoked are also revoked.
If you omit this clause, then CONTAINER = CURRENT is the default.
References:
questions.question_text:
In your multitenant container database (CDB) containing pluggable database (PDBs), you granted the CREATE TABLE privilege to the common user C # #
A_ADMIN in root and all PDBs. You execute the following command from the root container:
SQL > REVOKE create table FROM C # # A_ADMIN;
What is the result?

discussion.content: yeah this is a tricky one. when i read the portion "you granted the CREATE TABLE privilege to the common user C ## A_ADMIN in root and all PDBs". i incorrectly assumed that Container = All clause was implied in this scenario. I tested it by granting the system privilege separately and confirmed the answer is A

I tested it when you grant with container=all the privilege adds to all CDB and PDBS and the answer is B, but when you grant with separate in CDB and PDBS then answer is A, I hate this questions which not clear but tricky is there written "in root and all PDB". That means privilege given separate I think and answer is A.

comments.content: why? If you omit this clause, then CONTAINER = CURRENT is the default.

choices.A: It executes successfully and the CREATE TABLE privilege is revoked from C # # A_ADMIN in root only.
choices.D: It fails and reports an error because the CONTAINER=CURRENT clause is not used.
choices.B: It fails and reports an error because the CONTAINER=ALL clause is not used.
choices.C: It excludes successfully and the CREATE TABLE privilege is revoked from C # # A_ADMIN in root and all PDBs.
choices.E: It executes successfully and the CREATE TABLE privilege is revoked from C # # A_ADMIN in all PDBs.

discussion.content:
I agree B,C – is correct answer. 

See Prioritizing Jobs
http://docs.oracle.com/database/121/ADMIN/scheduse.htm#CIAEGDJB

Setting Relative Job Priorities Within a Job Class
http://docs.oracle.com/database/121/ADMIN/scheduse.htm#i1016329bis

questions.answer_description:
B: Job priorities are used only to prioritize among jobs in the same class.
Note: Group jobs for prioritization
Within the same job class, you can assign priority values of 1-5 to individual jobs so that if two jobs in the class are scheduled to start at the same time, the one with the higher priority takes precedence. This ensures that you do not have a less important job preventing the timely completion of a more important one.
C: Set resource allocation for member jobs
Job classes provide the link between the Database Resource Manager and the Scheduler, because each job class can specify a resource consumer group as an attribute. Member jobs then belong to the specified consumer group and are assigned resources according to settings in the current resource plan.

choices.A: Increasing the priority of the job class to which the job belongs
choices.C: Increasing the resource allocation for the consumer group mapped to the scheduler job's job class within the plan mapped to the scheduler window
choices.D: Moving the job to an existing higher priority scheduler window with the same schedule and duration
choices.F: Increasing the priority of the scheduler window to which the job belongs
choices.B: Increasing the job's relative priority within the Job class to which it belongs
choices.E: Increasing the value of the JOB_QUEUE_PROCESSES parameter

questions.question_text:
You notice that the elapsed time for an important database scheduler Job is unacceptably long.
The job belongs to a scheduler job class and window.
Which two actions would reduce the job's elapsed time? (Choose two.)

choices.C: Individual PDBs can be flashed back without flashing back the entire CDB.
choices.A: The root container can be flashed back without flashing back the pluggable databases (PDBs).
choices.D: The DB_FLASHBACK RETENTION_TARGET parameter must be set to enable flashback of the CDB.
choices.E: A CDB can be flashed back specifying the desired target point in time or an SCN, but not a restore point.
choices.B: To enable flashback database, the CDB must be mounted.
